title: Stomach ulcer medication recalled amid fears it has been contaminated with cancer-causing chemical, government warns
text:
A drug used to treat stomach ulcers has been recalled amid fears it has been contaminated with a cancer-causing chemical, the government has warned.

Healthcare professionals were told last night to stop supplying the products immediately, to quarantine all remaining stock and return it to their supplier.

Concerns have been raised that ranitiden, an active substance in the branded medication Zantac, may have been contaminated with NDMA, a chemical identified as a risk factor in the development of certain cancers.

Around 6 million prescriptions for ranitidine were issued in England last year, according to NHS Digital.

Four types of Zantac have been recalled by GlaxoSmithKline, the drugs manufacturer, including; 150mg (10ml) Syrup, Zantac 50mg (2ml) Injection, Zantac 150mg Tablets and Zantac 300mg Tablets.

All four drugs are prescription only medicines.

Last night the government body tasked with regulating drug safety, the Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA), issued a warning to healthcare professionals following an investigation.

But they advised patients do not stop taking their medication and seek their doctors advice.

It comes as fears about contamination were raised in the US last month, after retailer CVS removed Zantac from its shelves after officials found some pills contained traces of NDMA, also known as N-nitrosodimethylamine.
